Literature Review: The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) into healthcare has revolutionized the way we approach disease diagnosis, treatment, and prevention. Particularly, the application of these technologies in predicting health deterioration and understanding personalized disease pathways has garnered significant attention. This literature review delves into the current state of research on predictive models for health deterioration, focusing on the utilization of AI and ML in longitudinal analysis and the prediction of an individual patient's health status within personalized disease pathways. The exploration begins with an overview of the AI and ML methods employed in this domain, followed by a discussion on specific medical applications, strengths, limitations of current studies, and future research directions. AI and ML methods, including deep learning, neural networks, and time series analysis, have been pivotal in analyzing complex datasets to predict health outcomes. These methods excel in identifying patterns and correlations within large datasets, enabling the prediction of disease progression and health deterioration with remarkable accuracy. For instance, deep learning models have been successfully applied in predicting the progression of chronic diseases such as diabetes and cardiovascular diseases by analyzing electronic health records (EHRs) and time-series data (Rajkomar et al., 2018). Similarly, neural networks have been utilized to forecast the onset of acute conditions like sepsis in hospitalized patients, significantly improving early detection and intervention strategies (Shickel et al., 2018). Time series analysis, another critical method, has been employed to monitor and predict the health status of patients with chronic conditions, offering insights into disease trajectories and enabling personalized treatment plans (Che et al., 2018). The application of these predictive models spans various medical fields, including oncology, cardiology, and neurology, demonstrating their versatility and potential in enhancing patient care. Despite the promising advancements, the field faces several challenges. The accuracy of predictive models heavily relies on the quality and quantity of data, with issues such as data incompleteness, inconsistency, and bias posing significant hurdles (Topol, 2019). Moreover, the interpretability of AI and ML models remains a concern, as the 'black box' nature of these technologies can hinder their acceptance and integration into clinical practice (Caruana et al., 2015). Ethical and privacy concerns also arise with the use of sensitive health data, necessitating robust data protection measures and ethical guidelines (Price & Cohen, 2019). Looking ahead, future research should focus on addressing these limitations by improving data quality, enhancing model interpretability, and establishing ethical frameworks for data use. Additionally, the integration of multimodal data sources, including genomic, environmental, and lifestyle data, could further refine predictive models, paving the way for truly personalized medicine (Jiang et al., 2017). Collaborative efforts between data scientists, clinicians, and policymakers will be crucial in translating these technological advancements into clinical practice, ultimately improving patient outcomes and healthcare efficiency. In conclusion, AI and ML hold immense potential in predicting health deterioration and understanding personalized disease pathways. While challenges remain, ongoing research and technological advancements promise to overcome these obstacles, heralding a new era of personalized medicine.
